File.Title: Pathways Connecting the Right and Left Cochlear Nuclei
File.Authors: NELL B. CANT AND KAREN C. GASTON

Abstract.S: Connections between the right and left cochlear nuclei were studied with retrograde and anterograde axonal transport techniques.

Large, multipolar neurons in the anterior and posterior divisions of the anteroventral cochlear nucleus and in the posteroventral cochlear nucleus project to the ventral and dorsal cochlear nuclei on the opposite side.
In addition, giant cells in the deep layers of the dorsal cochlear nucleus project to the contralateral posteroventral cochlear nucleus and possibly also to the contralateral dorsal cochlear nucleus.
The pattern of terminal distribution of the crossed connections was determined by using the anterograde axonal transport of horseradish peroxidase-labelled wheat germ lectin.

Although no part of the cochlear nuclear complex is completely free of anterograde label, the densest labelling is found in the anterior division of the anteroventral cochlear nucleus, throughout the posteroventral cochlear nucleus (where it is closely associated with cell bodies), and in the fusiform and superficial layers of the dorsal cochlear nucleus.
These direct synaptic connections from one cochlear nucleus to the other could play a significant role in processes that depend on binaural interactions within the central nervous system.

Introduction.S: Although the projection of the cochlear nerve into the cochlear nuclear complex is exclusively ipsilateral, both the dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei contain neurons that are influenced binaurally.

In general, units in the dorsal cochlear nucleus may be either excited or inhibited by contralateral acoustic stimuli (Mast, '70, '73; Young and Brownell, '76), whereas units in the ventral cochlear nucleus are inhibited by contralateral sound (Pfalz, '62; Pirsig and Pfalz, '67; Pirsig et al., '68; Klinge et al., '69; Hochfeld, '73).

It has been assumed that the signals from the contralateral ear reach the cochlear nucleus via indirect pathways involving cell groups in the Superior OliVarY complex, the nuclei of the lateral lemniscus, or the inferior colliculus* For fVoups in the superior OlivaT comP1ex pmjed to One or both (Rasmussen, '60; Elverland, ,771, and those cell fVoup% in turn, receive inputs from the cochlear nuclei (Warr, '66, '72).

Thus, nuclei in the superior olive could relay acoustic information from one cochlear nucleus to the otherThe Passibility that there are direct connections between the right and left cochlear nuclear Complexes has received less attention, although there are brief reports of their existence (Adams, '76, '79; Adarns and Warr, '76).
In the present study, these direct connections were examined in more detail.

It was found that large neurons scattered throughout the ventral cochlear nucleus and also large neurons in the deep layers of the dorsal cochlear nucleus project to restricted parts of the contralateral cochlear nucleus.

Methods.S: METHODS
Thirty adult cats were used in the study.
~~~i~~ all experimental the animals were anesthetized with pentobarbital (35 mg/kg), Retrograde axonal transport of horseradish peroxidase (HRP)

To determine the distribution of neurons projecting into the cochlear nucleus, HRp (30% in 0.1 M phosphate buffer or 0.9% saline) was deposited iontophoretically through stereotaxically placed micropipettes with tip diameters of 15-30 km.
A positive current of 1.0 kamp was passed for minutes.
After a 24-hour survival period, the cats were perfused through the heart with a solution of 4% glutaraldehyde in o.l buffer.
The fixed brain was kept in 30% Bucrose at 4Â°C for 1 or 2 days and then cut as frozen sections 50-70 pm thick.
Every other section was processed for HRP reaction product with tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) as the substrate (Mesulam, '77).
The remaining sections made up two groups of every fourth section, one of which was reacted with o-tolidine (Somogyi et al., '79).
The other group of sections was mounted without reaction and stained darkly with cresylechtviolet.
All other sections were lightly counterstained with neutral red.
The TMB-reacted sections were used to determine the distribution of labelled cells and to estimate the maximum extent of the injection site.
The o-tolidine-reacted sections were used to determine the location of the pipette tip, where the HRP concentration was the highest.
This site could not always be determined in the TMB sections.
The unreaded, Nisslstained sections were used to determine cytoarchitectonic boundaries.
In a few early experiments, very large injections of HRP that fdled the entire cochlear nucleus were made by injecting the enzyme through a Hamilton syringe needle placed in the cochlear nucleus.
In these cases, every fifth section was reacted with TMB.

Because the pipettes were inserted into the cochlear nucleus from a dorsal approach through the cerebellum, control injections of HRP were made in two cases into the part of the cerebellum lying just dorsal to the cochlear nuclear complex.
In these two cases, numerous cells throughout the brainstem were labelled, but labelled neurons were never found in either cochlear nucleus.
Results were plotted on magnified drawings of the brainstem sections through the use of an X-Y plotter enslaved to a microscope stage.
Anterograde axonal transport of horseradish peroxidase-labelled wheat germ lectin

To demonstrate the terminal distribution of the crossed fibers in the cochlear nucleus, HFP-labelled wheat germ lectin (10% in saline) was iontophoretically deposited into one cochlear nucleus (injection parameters as above).
After a 1or %day survival, the animals were perfused through the heart with 10% formalin in 0.1 M phosphate buffer followed by a sucrose buffer washout.
The sections were processed as above except that benzidine dihydrochloride was used as a substrate for the reaction in place of otolidine.
Since neurons are also retrogradely labelled by this method, these cases were included in the analysis of the distribution of cells that project to the contralateral cochlear nucleus.
Measurements
To compare the average size of labelled neurons to that of unlabelled neurons, measurements were made of the cross-sectional area of selected cells in two of the cases.
The area of every labelled cell in every fourth section through the cochlear nucleus was measured with a digital planimeter.
For comparison, the area of every neuron within 150 pm of each labelled cell was also measured.
The cells in the TMB-reacted material are considerably shrunken compared to those in nonreacted Nissl material, but the relative sizes of various types of neurons do not appear to be affected.

Results.S: RESULTS
Retrograde transport of horseradish peroxidase (HRP) and of HRP-labelled wheat germ lectin
Large injections.

TTE.S: After very large injections of HRP that fill the entire cochlear nuclear complex, labelled neurons are widely scattered throughout the contralateral ventral cochlear nucleus (VCN) (Fig. 1A).
Labelled neurons may be located in either the anterior or posterior division of the anteroventral cochlear nucleus (AVCN) as well as throughout the posteroventral cochlear nucleus (PVCN).
Labelled cells are also found in the contralateral dorsal cochlear nucleus (DCN).
These labelled cells are always located in the deep or polymorphic cell layer of the DCN (Fig. 1A).
x-a ~~~, all cases, relatively few of the neurons in the VCN or in the DCN are labelled.

That the relative paucity of labelled neurons is not caused by insensitive reaction techniques is indicated by the observation of large numbers of labelled cells in the nuclei of the superior olivary complex that project to the injected cochlear nucleus (Fig. 1B).

Results.S: Restricted injections.
The large injections demonstrate that neurons in the AVCN, PVCN, and DCN project to the contralateral cochlear nucleus.

To determine whether these projections are reciprocal, with each part of the cochlear nucleus receiving inputs from its counterpart on the opposite side, or are arranged in some other way, iontophoretic injections of HRP, restricted to parts of the cochlear nucleus, were made.
In the most useful cases, the deposited HRP was confined to the AVCN or to the caudal cochlear nucleus (PVCN plus DCN) (Fig. 2).
Very small injections, completely confined to one subdivision of the AVCN or PVCN or to the DCN, resulted in no or very few labelled cells on the contralateral side.
Possibly the injection must be of a critical size before sufficient HRP is taken up to label the projecting cells.
However, as discussed below, conclusions drawn from the cases with medium-sized injections (as illustrated in Fig. 2) were corroborated by the results from those with very small injections.

TTE.S: The results of an injection confined mainly to the anterior division of the AVCN but with some overlap into the posterior division (injection site illustrated in Fig. 2A) are shown in Figure 3.
As in the cases with large injections, labelled neurons are found scattered throughout the contralateral AVCN and PVCN.
Injections in any part of the AVCN result in a qualitatively similar pattern of labelling.
Even with very small injections, labelled neurons are found in both the AVCN and PVCN on the opposite side.

For example, in one case (not illustrated) with a small injection confined to the anterior division of the AVCN, seven labelled neurons were found in a series of every fourth section through the contralateral AVCN.
Of these, two were in the AVCN and five were in the PVCN.
No labelled cells were ever found in the DCN after injections restricted to the contralateral AVCN.
The results of an injection centered in, and confined mainly to, the caudal cochlear nucleus (injection site illustrated in Fig. 2B) are shown in Figure 4.
Again, labelled neurons are present in all parts of the VCN.
In addition, labelled neurons are found in the deep layer of the DCN.

Results.S: This pattern of labelling is found in all cases of injections that include both the PVCN and DCN.

Smaller injections also revealed the projection from the VCN and DCN to the contralateral PVCN; however, small injections in the DCN confirmed only the projections to that structure from the contralateral VCN.

TTE.S: For example, one small injection (not illustrated) was confined to the PVCN.
In a series of every fourth section, eight labelled cells were found in the contralateral cochlear nucleus, two in the AVCN, five in the PVCN, and one in the DCN.
Three small injections (not illustrated) were confined to the DCN.
In these cases, every other section was searched for labelled cells.
In one of the cases, only one labelled cell was found in the contralateral cochlear nucleus and that was in the PVCN.
In another, seven labelled cells were found, two in the AVCN and five in the PVCN.
In the third case, only four labelled cells were found, all in the PVCN.

No labelled cells were found in the opposite DCN in any of these cases; however, the injections were so small that it is not reasonable to conclude on these grounds alone that the DCN does not receive projections from its counterpart on the opposite side.

Results.S: Cell types.
In some cases, the HRP reaction product fills not only the soma of a labelled cell but also its dendrites (Fig. 5).
In every instance in which labelled cells in the contralateral VCN are so filled, the cells can be identified as large multipolar neurons (Fig. 5A,B).

Even in the anterior division of the AVCN, in which very few large multipolar cells are present (Osen, '69; Brawer et al., '74; Cant and Morest, '79a), the labelled cells are like those shown in Figure 5.

To confirm the impression that the labelled neurons are larger than the average neurons in the VCN, the crosssectional areas of the somata of all labelled neurons in the sections illustrated in Figures 3 and 4 were measured and compared to the areas of the somata of all unlabelled cells within 150 pm of the labelled ones.
The results, illustrated in Figure 6, indicate that the neurons projecting to the contralateral cochlear nucleus are indeed among the largest neurons in the VCN.
The neurons labelled in the DCN can be identified as giant cells (Fig. 5C), only a few of which are labelled in any given case.
In cases in which portions of the dendrites are labelled as well as the cell bodies, the cells appear to be vertical giant cells (Fig. 5C; cf.
Brawer et al., '74).
Anterograde transport of HRP-labelled wheat germ lectin
Distribution of label in the cochlear nucleus.

TTE.S: To determine more precisely the redons of the ventral and dorsal cochlear nuclei that receive inputs from the conHRP-labelled wheat germ lettin was injected into one cochlear nucleus.
This method Proved to be very effective for labelling sparse Pathways.'
A typical result is shown in Figure 7.
It is possible that axon collaterals of the retrogradely labelled cells, if they existed, could also be labelled using this method, thereby contaminating the results.

However, for several reasons, it seems reasonable to assume that most, if not all, of the label not located within cell bodies in these cases is attributable to the axons projecting from the contralateral cochlear nucleus.
First, in many cases, the axons of retrogradely labelled cells can be followed for considerable distances from the cell body (e.g., fig. 5A,B), but axon collaterals are never seen arising from them.
Also, bundles of axons and single axons can be traced into the nucleus from fiber pathways medial to it.
After entering, they arborize and form terminal swellings (cf.
If these axons are collaterals, they do not arise until the parent axons are far outside the nucleus.
Furthermore, labelled axons in these fiber bundles are not seen to branch.

Compared to other brainstem nuclei that receive projections from the cochlear nucleus,the anterograde label in the contralateral cochlear nucleus is relatively sparse; however, since there is virtually no random background label with this method, even sparsely labelled nuclei are distinctly different from unlabelled nuclei.
Photographs of anterogradely labelled axons and terminals are shown in Figure 8.

Because the sections are quite thick and the contrast of the reaction product in black and white photographs is rather low, the anterograde label and its relation to cell bodies is more easily appreciated in drawings (Fig. 9).
Many branching axons were seen in the labelled VCN and DCN in all the cases (Figs. 8A, 9A,B).
In addition, small, focal accumulations of HRP reaction product, presumably representing axonal terminals, were distributed throughout the nucleus (Figs.
BC, 9C,D).
These experiments provide evidence for a differential distribution of the axons projecting from the opposite cochlear nucleus.

Although no region of the cochlear nuclear complex was completely free of label, the densest labelling was found in the anterior division of the AVCN, throughout the PVCN, and in the superficial and fusiform layers of the DCN (Figs. 7 and 9).
In the AVCN, most of the labelling is distributed among the bushy cells of the anterior division (Fig. 9D).

Some of the label is proximate to cell bodies but most of it is found in the neuropil, which, in the anterior part of the AVCN must consist almost entirely of bushy cell dendrites (Cant and Morest, '79a).
In the PVCN, the anterograde label is almost always associated with cell bodies (Fig. 9C).
The pericellular labelling is present throughout the PVCN, in the octopus cell areas as well as in the other subdivisions.

Results.S: Even with small injections confined to the AVCN or to the PVCN, terminal labelling was found throughout the contralateral cochlear nucleus, although the labelling was even sparser.
Possible routes taken by axons from one cochlear nucleus to the other.

Although complete axons could not be traced from one side to the other, bundles of axons 'In preliminary experiments, using standard autoradiographic techniques, we injected tritiated amino acids into one cochlear nuclear complex.
The projections fmm the cochlear nucleus to the superior olivary complex were easily seen in these cases.

However, even with very large injections, the label in the contralateral cochlear nucleus was never convincingly above background, Although, occasionally, gains were lined up in a way suggestive that they overlay axons, information about the distribution of the projecting axons within the cochlear nuclear complex could not be obtained from these experiments.
could be followed from the margins of the cochlear nucleus contralateral to the injection into two potential routes through which they might cross the midline (Fig. 10).
First, some of the axons can be traced dorsally into the dorsal acoustic stria (arrow in section 27, Fig. 10, and structure labelled DAS in sections 19 and 23).

Second, some axons penetrate the spinal tract and nucleus of the fXth nerve medially to join the dorsal acoustic stria from the other side at the point at which it joins the lateral lemniscus (curved arrow in section 30, Fig. 10).
No labelled axons are found in the trapezoid body just medial to the cochlear nucleus contralateral to the injection site.
The diagram in Figure 10B is based on case C150 and others and summarizes the possible routes.

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION

In the present study, retrograde and anterograde tracing techniques have been used to demonstrate direct connections between the right and left cochlear nuclei and to determine some of the details of the origins, course, and Planar Area of Cell Body (jm2)
terminations of the projections.
Figure 11 is a summary diagram of the conclusions of the study.
The crossed pathways originate in giant cells of the dorsal cochlear nucleus and in large multipolar neurons located throughout the ventral cochlear nucleus (VCN).

Although, in general, the morphology of cell types in the VCN is quite different from one subdivision to the next, the neurons that project to the contralateral cochlear nucleus are quite similar to one another regardless of the subdivision of origin.
It appears that this is at least one special case of a population of neurons that does not respect the boundaries of the subdivisions.
The crossed pathway does not terminate uniformly throughout the recipient cochlear nucleus.

Although all parts of the complex contain some anterograde label, the densest labelling is found in the anterior division of the anteroventral cochlear nucleus, in most of the posteroventral cochlear nucleus, and in the superficial layers of the dorsal cochlear nucleus.
The projection from one cochlear nuclear complex to the other is not strictly reciprocal.
Indeed, many of the cells of origin are located in the parts of the complex that receive the sparsest projection.
It was not possible to determine with the available material whether a given neuron projects to both the rostral and caudal cochlear nuclei.
This seems likely to be the case, however, since the numbers of labelled cells did not increase markedly from medium-sized to large injections.
Relation to previous studies
Cell types that form the projection.
The cells that project to the contralateral cochlear nucleus are among the largest neurons in the complex.
The presence of large multipolar or giant cells in the ventral cochlear nucleus has been noted in several species (Harrison and Irving, '65; Osen and Jansen, '65; Osen, '69; Brawer et al., '74).

In the cat, the giant cells of the AVCN are most numerous dorsally and caudally (Osen, '69; Brawer et al., '741, a distribution fairly similar to that of the labelled cells in the AVCN seen in the present study (cf.
Whether all giant cells of the VCN project to the contralateral cochlear nucleus is unknown.
A number of types of giant cells have been described in the deep layer of the dorsal cochlear nucleus (Brawer et al., '74; Kane et al., '81).
The labelled giant cells seen after HRP injections in the contralateral cochlear nucleus appear to be of the class named vertical (Brawer et al., '74) or oriented giant cells (Kane et al., '81).
The oriented giant cells are located in the deepest part of the DCN as are the labelled cells in the present study.
Very few giant cells in the DCN are labelled even after very large injections.
Likewise, Kane et al. ('81) note that the oriented giant cells are relatively rare.
It may be that this class of neurons makes up a small population whose target is the contralateral cochlear nucleus.
The soma and proximal dendrites of the oriented giant cells defined by Kane et al. ('81) appear to make synaptic contact with both cochlear and noncochlear inputs.
Cell types that receive the projection.
After injections of HRP-labelled wheat germ lectin, anterograde label is present in all parts of the contralateral cochlear nucleus.
In the AVCN, most of the label lies in the neuropil of the anterior division.

In the rostral part of this division, almost the only cell type present is the bushy cell (Cant and Morest, '79a) so that it is likely that some of the crossed fibers are forming synaptic connections with the bushy cells.
Since the label is found mainly in the neuropil, not associated with cell bodies, the contacts are probably with the dendrites or dendritic appendages of these cells.
Some of the synaptic contacts made with the bushy cell dendrites arise in the cochlea, but many of them do not (Cant and Morest, '79b).
The results of the present study suggest that at least some of the noncochlear contacts arise in the contralateral cochlear nucleus.
In the PVCN, almost all the anterograde label is located next to cell bodies.
Only in the posterior part of the nucleus could the cell types be definitely identified.
This part of the nucleus contains only octopus cells (Osen, '69; Brawer et al., '74) so it is likely that the octopus cell receives synaptic inputs from the opposite cochlear nucleus.
Kane ('73) described a type of noncochlear terminal that forms synapses on the soma of the octopus cell.
At least some of these may arise in the crossed projections.

The numerous cell types distinguishable in Golgi preparations of the other parts of the PVCN (Brawer et al., '74) have not been described in detail in Nissl material so that we could not readily identify the cell types associated with label in other parts of the nucleus; however, it is clear that many of the larger cell types are surrounded by label.

In the DCN, the anterograde label is found mainly in the fusiform cell layer, where it could be associated with cell bodies of fusiform and/or small cells, and in the superficial layer, where there could be inputs to the apical dendrites of the fusiform cells or to the cell bodies and dendrites of the small cells located there (Osen, '69; Brawer et al., '74).
Although it must be confirmed by electron microscopy, the suggested association of labelled terminals with some types of neuronal cell bodies is potentially very important.
Even with very large injections in the contralateral nucleus, the anterograde label is quite sparse relative to that seen in other nuclei receiving input from the cochlear nucleus.
However, if the terminals form synaptic contacts on neuronal cell bodies, even this sparse pathway could be in a position to influence strongly the activity of the neurons.
Nonprimary inputs to the cochlear nucleus.

Axons that may correspond to the crossed pathway have been described in a number of studies based on Golgi preparations (Held, 1893; Feldman and Harrison, '69; Cant and Morest, '78; Lorente de N6, '81).

In a detailed study of noncochlear axons in the AVCN, Cant and Morest ('78) described three groups of axons in kittens that arise outside the cochlear nucleus and enter the AVCN along its medial aspect.

The terminals of both the group I and the group I11 axons described by them are distributed mainly to the anterior division, similar to the distribution of the anterograde label seen in the present study, but the group 111 axons seem the most similar to the projection described here.
For example, the branching pattern of the filled axons resembles that of the group 111 axons seen in Gold impregnations (compare our Fig. 8A to Fig. 7 of Cant and Morest, '78).
Also, the terminals of the group 111 axons are found mainly in the neuropil, away from cell bodies, comparable to the distribution of the reaction product in the AVCN in the present study.
The distribution of noncochlear axons has also been described in Golgi studies of the DCN (Kane, '74).
Kane's axons of classes 2 and 3 travel within the molecular and fusiform cell layers forming small boutons en passant.
Their pattern of termination is similar to that of the labelled axons seen in the DCN in the present study (e.g., compare our Fig. 8B to her Fig. 11).
Physiological studies.

Contralateral acoustic stimulation has been shown to affect the firing level of cochlear nuclear neurons (Pfalz, '62; Pirsig and Pfalz, '67; Pirsig et al., '68; Klinge et al., '69; Hochfeld, '73; Mast, '70, '73; Young and Brownell, '76).

Unfortunately, most of the reports of the physiological effects of contralateral acoustic stimuli on the activity of cochlear nuclear neurons have not included localization of the recording sites so that often it is not even clear whether the records are from the VCN or the DCN.
Presumably, the recordings covered wide areas of the nucleus, but the data are insufficient to allow more than a very general correlation with the anatomical data presented here.
What is clear from these studies is that the effect of contralateral acoustic stimulation on cochlear nuclear neurons is predominantly inhibitory.
The direct pathway between the cochlear nuclei may be responsible for this effect.
In several studies the recording sites were more precisely known, being limited to the DCN (Mast, '70, '73; Young and Brownell, '76).
In the cat, Young and Brownell found that moat of the neurons classified as type II/III and as type IV could be either inhibited or excited or both by contralateral stimuli.
If, as they suggest, the type I11 units correspond to small interneurons (small cells?)

and the type IV units to fusiform cells, then the crossed pathway described in the present study might easily account for the binaural response properties seen physiologically since the pathways to the DCN appear to terminate around both fusiform cells and small cells.
Functional significance
Although the function of the crossed pathways is not known, a consideration of some of their main sites of termination leads to speculation about possible functions of the connections.
The inputs to the AVCN terminate mainly in the anterior division, and, as discussed above, it is very likely that at least some of the crossing fibers form synapses on the bushy cells.
The bushy cells, in turn, project to the medial and lateral superior olivary nuclei (MSO, LSO) (Warr, '66; Own, '70; unpublished observations).

A number of lines of evidence implicate the LSO and the MSO in the neural analyses of binaural intensity and timing differences that provide the central nervous system with information relevant to the location of sound sources (e.g., Neff, '62; Masterton et al., '67; Moushegian et al., '67; Goldberg and Brown, '69; Boudreau and Tsuchitani, '70; Moore et al., '74; Masterton et al., '75).

Thus, since any inputs to the bushy cells would also probably influence this function, the neurons that interconnect the two ventral cochlear nuclei could play a role in encoding differences in intensity and timing of stimuli at the two ears.

For example, impulses arriving earlier at one ear might result in activity in the crossed pathway that would modulate the response to the same stimulus at the opposite ear, either changing its firing rate, or, since an important variable must be timing of the discharges, changing the latency between the synaptic potentials and the subsequent discharges and thereby resulting in changes in the timing of impulses.
A possible result is an enhancement of the intensity or timing differences at the level of the cochlear nuclei.
Some of the inputs to the PVCN are found in the caudal parts where octopus cells are numerous.

Many of the cella in this part of the VCN respond only to the onset of an acoustic stimulus (Godfrey et al., '751, and, like the bushy cells, the exact timing of their discharges is likely to be an important variable.
Again, crossed inputs from the contralateral cochlear nucleus might influence the timing of the impulses of the odopus cells.
As pointed out by Godfrey et al. ('751, it is premature to postulate a specific role for these onset units.
Whatever their function, however, interconnections between the two cochlear nuclei could serve to influence the timing of their discharges and to coordinate responses from the two ears.
Thus, as emphasized some time ago by Erulkar ('721, the cochlear nucleus may play an important role in the analysis of binaural inputs.
The crossed pathway described in the present study could form the anatomical basis for this particular function.
